entry.content:
OpenAI, one week ago:

Today we‚Äôre introducing ChatGPT Atlas, a new web browser built with ChatGPT at its core.

AI gives us a rare moment to rethink what it means to use the web. Last year, we added search in ChatGPT so you could instantly find timely information from across the internet‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand it quickly became one of our most-used features. But your browser is where all of your work, tools, and context come together. A browser built with ChatGPT takes us closer to a true super-assistant that understands your world and helps you achieve your goals.

A few minutes into the 22-minute introduction video, Ben Goodger,1 engineering lead for Atlas, says:

‚ÄúWe wanted to make sure that Atlas didn‚Äôt feel like your old browser, just with a chat button that was bolted on. But instead, we made ChatGPT the beating heart of Atlas.‚Äù

After giving it a try over the last week, to me Atlas feels like ‚Ä¶ Chrome with a chat button bolted on. I do not see the appeal, at all, despite being a daily user of ChatGPT. Atlas offers nothing of any appeal to me that‚Äôs better than using Safari as a standalone browser and ChatGPT‚Äôs excellent native Mac app as a standalone AI chatbot. But, for me, my browser is not ‚Äúwhere all of [my] work, tools, and context come together‚Äù. I use an email app for email, a notes app for notes, a text editor and blog editor for writing and programming, a photos app for my photo library, a native feed reader app for feed reading, etc. My web browser is for browsing pages on the web. Perhaps this sort of browser/chat hybrid appeals only to people who live the majority of their desktop-computing lives in browser tabs.

  • The main interface isn‚Äôt a combo search/location field, but rather a chat/location field. Instead of getting search results for a query, you get a chat response. If I wanted this I‚Äôd just ask my prompt in ChatGPT. Oftentimes‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâusually, even‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâI really do want a list of search results, and I want them fast. ChatGPT responses in Atlas are not a list of web pages, and are‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâcompared to Google Search or my preferred search engine, Kagi‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâvery slow. ChatGPT is many things but a good search engine replacement it is not. But that seems to be the entire premise of Atlas.

  • Atlas offers an agent mode where it actually surfs the web for you. One of the demos from their launch video involved getting a list of ingredients from a recipe on a web page, and then allowing Atlas to buy all those ingredients for you. That seems crazy to me. Do not want.

  • Atlas is a Chromium browser, supports Chrome extensions, and but currently is only available for the Mac. It‚Äôs not particularly Mac-like though, as Michael Tsai notes:

    Alas, it doesn‚Äôt support AppleScript and has System Settings‚Äìstyle preferences.

    System Settings-style preferences are certainly better than Chrome-style ‚Äúsettings in a web page tab‚Äù, though. Also, in my testing, Atlas doesn‚Äôt make good use of Apple Passwords for autofill.

  • ChatGPT is running a promotion that offers users increased rate limits if they make‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand keep‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâAtlas their default web browser. I‚Äôve never before seen a web browser offer any sort of incentive like this for making it your default. This promotion strikes me as simultaneously clever and icky.

  • Simon Willison‚Äôs initial thoughts echo my own:

    I continue to find this entire category of browser agents deeply confusing.

    The security and privacy risks involved here still feel insurmountably high to me‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâI certainly won‚Äôt be trusting any of these products until a bunch of security researchers have given them a very thorough beating. [...]

    I also find these products pretty unexciting to use. I tried out agent mode and it was like watching a first-time computer user painstakingly learn to use a mouse for the first time. I have yet to find my own use-cases for when this kind of interaction feels useful to me, though I‚Äôm not ruling that out.

  • Lastly, Anil Dash‚Äôs assessment is rather scathing, ‚ÄúThe Browser That‚Äôs Anti-Web‚Äù:

    In the demo for Atlas, the OpenAI team shows a user trying to find a Google Doc from their browser history. A normal user would type keywords like ‚Äúatlas design‚Äù and see their browser show a list of recent pages. They would recognize the phrase ‚ÄúGoogle Docs‚Äù or the icon, and click on it to get back to where they were.

    But in the OpenAI demo, the team member types out:

    search web history for a doc about atlas core design

    This is worse in every conceivable way. It‚Äôs slower, more prone to error, and redundant. But it also highlights one of the biggest invisible problems: you‚Äôre switching ‚Äúmodes‚Äù. Normally, an LLM‚Äôs default mode is to create plausible extrapolations based on its training data. Basically, it‚Äôs supposed to make things up. But this demo has to explicitly walk you through ‚Äúnow it‚Äôs time to go search my browser history‚Äù because it‚Äôs coercing the AI to look through local content.

    Chat is a great interface for, well, chatting. People love texting. And it turns out that chat conversations are a very good user interface for interacting with LLMs. We humans enjoy texting with other humans, and we enjoy texting with LLMs. But typed-out text commands are not a good user interface at all for browsing the web. We had an entirely text-based Internet before the World Wide Web, and the point-and-click visual metaphor of the Web won out.

    Dash, later on:

    It‚Äôs no coincidence that hundreds of people who work at OpenAI, including many of the most powerful executives, are alumni of Facebook/Meta, especially during the era of many of that company‚Äôs most egregious abuses of people‚Äôs privacy. In the marketing materials and demonstrations of Atlas, OpenAI‚Äôs team describes the browser as being able to be your ‚Äúagent‚Äù, performing tasks on your behalf.

    But in reality, you are the agent for ChatGPT.

    During setup, Atlas pushes very aggressively for you to turn on ‚Äúmemories‚Äù (where it tracks and stores everything you do and uses it to train an AI model about you) and to enable ‚ÄúAsk ChatGPT‚Äù on any website, where it‚Äôs following along with you as you browse the web. By keeping the ChatGPT sidebar open while you browse, and giving it permission to look over your shoulder, OpenAI can suddenly access all kinds of things on the internet that they could never get to on their own.

    This jibes with my impression after giving Atlas a try. The point of it doesn‚Äôt seem to be providing a better web browser for me to use, but rather, to provide ChatGPT with the personal context of my digital life that it otherwise couldn‚Äôt get.

That last point raises the question of just how stable we should consider the Apple-OpenAI partnership for ChatGPT-backed Apple Intelligence features. Apple‚Äôs goal for a ‚Äúmore personalized Siri‚Äù‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthe whole thing Apple promised at WWDC 2024 but had to postpone for a full year early this year‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâis for the ecosystem of native apps on Apple platforms, particularly iOS and MacOS, to serve as the personal knowledge context for personalized AI features through App Intents. That‚Äôs the basis for the ‚ÄúWhen is my mom‚Äôs flight arriving?‚Äù type of interaction that Apple has promised, but still has not delivered. The premise of Atlas (and its brethren AI-integrated browsers like The Browser Company‚Äôs Dia and Perplexity‚Äôs Comet) is that you should live your entire desktop computing life inside your browser, which in turn will give the AI agent that is integrated with your browser the contextual knowledge for your entire life.

OpenAI‚Äôs ambitions are clearly at odds with Apple‚Äôs.

OpenAI‚Äôs advantage here is that ChatGPT is the most popular LLM chatbot in the world, by far. Apple doesn‚Äôt even have an LLM chatbot of its own, let alone a good or popular one. But Apple‚Äôs advantage is a big one: most people don‚Äôt live their digital lives on desktop computers, where it‚Äôs an option to do most things in a web browser. Most people‚Äôs primary computing devices are their phones‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand even for people whose primary devices are desktop computers, their phones are much-used satellite devices. And on both iOS and Android alike, people live their mobile digital lives through native apps, not websites.

  1. Goodger is a titanic figure in the web browser world, having helped create Mozilla Firefox in the early 2000s, and then joining Google in 2005 to help create Chrome. I noted last year that Goodger leaving Google for OpenAI was a pretty clear sign that OpenAI was creating its own web browser. ↩︎

entry.content:
Sam Tobin, reporting last week for Reuters:

Apple abused its dominant position by charging app developers unfair commissions, a London tribunal ruled on Thursday, in a blow which could leave the U.S. tech company on the hook for hundreds of millions of pounds in damages. The Competition Appeal Tribunal (CAT) ruled against Apple after a trial of the lawsuit, which was brought on behalf of millions of iPhone and iPad users in the United Kingdom.

The CAT ruled that Apple had abused its dominant position from October 2015 until the end of 2020 by shutting out competition in the app distribution market and by ‚Äúcharging excessive and unfair prices‚Äù as commission to developers. [...] The case had been valued at around 1.5 billion pounds ($2 billion) by those who brought it. A hearing next month will decide how damages are calculated and Apple‚Äôs application for permission to appeal.

Dan Moren and I discussed this at some length in the new episode of The Talk Show that dropped over the weekend. What makes this ruling interesting isn‚Äôt that it‚Äôs particularly significant or different from other regulatory/antitrust investigations around the world. It‚Äôs the fact that it‚Äôs completely in line with other regulatory/antitrust investigations regarding the App Store (and Play Store) from around the world.

When is the last time an investigation regarding the legality of the App Store‚Äôs dominant market position went in Apple‚Äôs favor, in any country? I can‚Äôt recall one. Apple is clearly fighting a losing battle here. Whether Apple ought to be losing all these legal and regulatory battles regarding the App Store is, from a strategic standpoint, almost irrelevant. The obvious fact is, they are losing them.

Apple has approached all this regulatory conflict from a perspective that they‚Äôre right, and the regulators are wrong. That the App Store, as Apple wants it, is (a) good for users, (b) fair to developers, and (c) competitive, not anti-competitive, legally. But even if Apple is correct about that, at some point, after being handed loss after loss in rulings from courts and regulatory bodies around the globe, shouldn‚Äôt they change their strategy and start trying to offer their own concessions, rather than wait for bureaucrat-designed concessions to be forced upon them?

However Apple thinks all of this should work out is not the way it is working out. The best time to adjust the rules of the App Store‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâits exclusivity on app distribution for the entire iOS platform, the exclusivity of Apple‚Äôs IAP for purchasing digital content, the commission percentage splits on IAP‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwas over a decade ago. The next best time to make those adjustments is now.

entry.title: ‚ÄòBoring Is What We Wanted‚Äô
entry.content:
Stephen Hackett, writing at 512 Pixels:

Apple silicon has been nothing but upside for the Mac, and yet some seem bored already. In the days since Apple announced the M5, I‚Äôve seen and heard this sentiment more than I expected:

This is just another boring incremental upgrade.

That üëè is üëè the üëè point.

Back in the PowerPC and Intel days, Macs would sometimes go years between meaningful spec bumps, as Apple waited on its partners to deliver appropriate hardware for various machines. From failing NVIDIA cards in MacBook Pros to 27-inch Intel iMacs that ran so hot the fans were audible at all times, Mac hardware wasn‚Äôt always what Apple wanted.

Consider the MacBook Air‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâby all accounts the most popular Mac Apple sells. There was a March 2015 update, and then a very minor speed bump in June 2017. That June 2017 update was so insignificant that it didn‚Äôt even warrant its own press release from Apple. All it got from Apple was, at the very end of a press release touting updates to the iMac, MacBook Pro, and late great 12-inch MacBook, this single sentence: ‚ÄúApple today also updated the 13-inch MacBook Air with a 1.8 GHz processor.‚Äù

It wasn‚Äôt until the very end of October 2018 that Apple released a significant MacBook Air update‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthe first models with retina displays. For the three-and-a-half-year stretch between March 2015 and October 2018, there wasn‚Äôt a single notable MacBook Air refresh‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâat a time when all other Macs had gone retina. Intel‚Äôs processor offerings were so unpalatable during that stretch that Apple just didn‚Äôt update their most popular Mac model.

entry.title: Reddit Files Lawsuit Accusing ‚ÄòData Scraper‚Äô Companies of Stealing Its Information
entry.content:
Mike Isaac, reporting for The New York Times:

Eight years ago, SerpApi, a start-up in Austin, Texas, dived headlong into the byzantine world of using robots to ‚Äúscrape‚Äù Google‚Äôs search algorithms, so it could collect information to help customers appear higher in search results.

Then OpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT came along, kicking off an artificial intelligence revolution. As more tech companies began building A.I. chatbots to keep up, they needed large amounts of data to train their A.I. models‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâdata that SerpApi had already gathered.

Practically overnight, a class of companies like SerpApi‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâknown as ‚Äúdata scrapers‚Äù‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâfound a new business selling data scraped from Google to companies looking to train their A.I. chatbots.

On Wednesday, the internet message board Reddit decided to fight the data scrapers. It filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York claiming that four companies had illegally stolen its data by scraping Google search results in which Reddit content appeared.

I‚Äôd never heard of‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâor at least never noticed‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâSerpApi until a few weeks ago, when a good friend asked me if I‚Äôd ever looked into them. The entire premise of their business is crazy. SerpApi prints the crime right on the tin, describing their service as a ‚ÄúGoogle Search API‚Äù and ‚ÄúScrape Google and other search engines from our fast, easy, and complete API.‚Äù What makes this so crazy is that Google doesn‚Äôt offer a search API. SerpApi is offering the Google search API that Google itself doesn‚Äôt offer, and charging companies money for it. Everyone, upon hearing the premise and nature of SerpApi, asks the same question: How is this legal? The answer is, it probably isn‚Äôt. But right on SerpApi‚Äôs home page they claim to offer customers a ‚ÄúU.S. Legal Shield‚Äù:

The crawling and parsing of public data is protected by the First Amendment of the United States Constitution. We value freedom of speech tremendously. We assume scraping and parsing liabilities for both domestic and foreign companies unless your usage is otherwise illegal. (Including but are not limited to: acts of cyber criminality, terrorism, pedopornography, denial of service attacks, and war crimes.)

My only surprise here is that it‚Äôs Reddit taking SerpApi (along with two similar companies, one from Lithuania and the other from Russia‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthe former Soviet states respect intellectual property about as much as China does) to court, not Google. Why Google hasn‚Äôt sued them yet, I don‚Äôt understand. Anyway, back to Isaac‚Äôs report for the Times:

Perplexity was one of those buyers, according to Reddit‚Äôs lawsuit. Perplexity had scraped Reddit data in the past without payment but agreed to stop after Reddit sent it a cease-and-desist order. Even so, citations to Reddit data in Perplexity search results jumped ‚Äúfortyfold,‚Äù the lawsuit said. Reddit has spent tens of millions of dollars on anti-scraping systems over several years.

‚ÄúPerplexity‚Äôs business model is effectively to take Reddit‚Äôs content from Google search results,‚Äù then feed it into an A.I. model and ‚Äúcall it a new product,‚Äù the lawsuit said.

Reddit said it had set a trap for Perplexity by creating a ‚Äútest post‚Äù on its site that could ‚Äúonly be crawled by Google‚Äôs search engine and was not otherwise accessible anywhere on the internet.‚Äù Within hours, Perplexity search results had surfaced the content of that test post, the lawsuit said.

Google, which is not a plaintiff in Reddit‚Äôs lawsuit, has tried and failed to stop SerpApi and other data scrapers, according to the lawsuit and previous reporting from The Information.

The people leading Perplexity aren‚Äôt just shifty‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthey‚Äôre stupid. That whole company just reeks of being a scam.

entry.title: Signal Moves Ahead on Post-Quantum Computing, But Still Sucks Ass When You Switch Phones
entry.content:
Graeme Connell and Rolfe Schmidt, writing earlier this month on the Signal blog:

We are excited to announce a significant advancement in the security of the Signal Protocol: the introduction of the Sparse Post Quantum Ratchet (SPQR). This new ratchet enhances the Signal Protocol‚Äôs resilience against future quantum computing threats while maintaining our existing security guarantees of forward secrecy and post-compromise security. [...]

What does this mean for you as a Signal user? First, when it comes to your experience using the app, nothing changes. Second, because of how we‚Äôre rolling this out and mixing it in with our existing encryption, eventually all of your conversations will move to this new protocol without you needing to take any action. Third, and most importantly, this protects your communications both now and in the event that cryptographically relevant quantum computers eventually become a reality, and it allows us to maintain our existing security guarantees of forward secrecy and post-compromise security as we proactively prepare for that new world.

It is impressive that Signal is ahead of the curve on post-quantum computing. Right now it takes me over 30 minutes to switch Signal from one phone to another, and I‚Äôm not a particularly heavy user of the app. Normal people don‚Äôt use Signal because it offers, by far, the worst and most limited user experience of any major messaging app. Signal is never going to get most people to even give the app a fair chance when the user experience is so much worse than Apple Messages and WhatsApp.

Again, I don‚Äôt mean to disparage the technical ingenuity of their post-quantum ratchet achievement. But they‚Äôre bragging about defenses against hypothetical threats from the future when, right now today, you still can‚Äôt use the same Signal account from two different phones.

entry.summary: Two new(ish) iPhone camera apps that take decidedly different approaches to distinguish themselves from Apple‚Äôs built-in Camera app.
entry.content:
I took the above photo on Monday, June 9, this year at WWDC. Keynote day, around 1:30pm PT. I captured it using my iPhone 16 Pro and Not Boring‚Äôs !Camera app, using the built-in Mono Tokyo LUT. Like the other apps in Not Boring‚Äôs growing suite, !Camera can be mistaken by the too-cynical as a toy. It is fun and colorful, and some of its features exist for the sake of fun alone. But, just like Not Boring‚Äôs other offerings (my favorites: !Weather, !Calculator, and !Habits), it‚Äôs a genuinely serious tool. And of the bunch, I think !Camera is the most innovative. The fact that it‚Äôs fun makes me want to use it‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâa vastly underestimated attribute of tool design. From Not Boring‚Äôs website:

Go from snap to sharing without any editing. !Camera is the first camera app to enable professional-level color grading with 3D LUTs (‚Äúlookup tables‚Äù) used in high-end workflows by pro photographers to achieve realistic film simulations and unique cinematic looks. Use !Camera‚Äôs designed presets, add LUTs from your favorite creators, or make and import your own! New Styles and collaborations released every season.

!Camera looks gimmicky but I assure you it‚Äôs not‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand what might strike you as gimmicky is really just plain fun and whimsical. My affection for it, and my use of it, has grown, not shrunk, as the months have gone by. While my hardware Camera Control buttons (plural, as I‚Äôm currently testing multiple iPhones) remain set to open Apple‚Äôs own Camera app, which I continue to use by default, I keep !Camera‚Äôs simple widget on my iPhones‚Äô Lock Screens to launch it quickly after unpocketing my iPhone.

!Camera‚Äôs use of LUTs for filter-like effects opens the app to a wide world of non-proprietary looks. The best source I‚Äôve found for new LUTs to import is the Panasonic LUMIX Lab app‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄâPanasonic‚Äôs built-in LUTs are boring, but the app has a whole community of user-submitted LUTs and I‚Äôve found several of them that are lovely. !Camera‚Äôs custom ‚ÄúSuperRAW‚Äù format, is, in my opinion, key to the appeal of the app:

No more flat lifeless photos, no AI processing, no weird artifacts. Our SuperRaw‚Ñ¢ photo processing has been crafted to showcase more film-like tones and preserve a photo‚Äôs beautiful natural grain.

Rather than fighting the nature of the small (and thus, noisy) sensors in the iPhone camera systems, SuperRAW processing embraces the noise, imbuing images with natural-looking grain. The results, to my eyes, are genuinely film-like. If you want, you can configure !Camera to save a raw DNG file alongside each capture, for post-processing in an app like Darkroom, Lightroom, or Photoshop. I‚Äôm glad that option is there, but I just shoot in SuperRAW, which saves ready-to-share HEIC files with the LUT applied in my camera roll, so what I see is what I get.

Each of Not Boring‚Äôs apps is available for a $15/year subscription, but the way to go is Not Boring‚Äôs $50/year ‚ÄúSuper !Boring‚Äù subscription, which grants you a license to their entire suite of apps. I was already a Super !Boring subscriber when !Camera launched, so, effectively, I got it for free. $50/year isn‚Äôt nothing, but it‚Äôs not much, and subscriptions have proven to be the best monetization strategy for indie developers in today‚Äôs world.

Project Indigo

Marc Levoy, Adobe fellow, and Florian Kainz, principal scientist, on the Adobe Research blog back in June:

Second, people often complain about the ‚Äúsmartphone look‚Äù‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâoverly bright, low contrast, high color saturation, strong smoothing, and strong sharpening. To some extent this look is driven by consumer preference. It also makes photos easier to read on the small screen and in bad lighting. But to the discerning photographer, or anybody who views these photos on a larger screen than a phone, they may look unrealistic. [...]

What‚Äôs different about computational photography using Indigo? First, we under-expose more strongly than most cameras. Second, we capture, align, and combine more frames when producing each photo‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâup to 32 frames as in the example above. This means that our photos have fewer blown-out highlights and less noise in the shadows. Taking a photo with our app may require slightly more patience after pressing the shutter button than you‚Äôre used to, but after a few seconds you‚Äôll be rewarded with a better picture.

As a side benefit of these two strategies, we need less spatial denoising (i.e. smoothing) than most camera apps. This means we preserve more natural textures. In fact, we bias our processing towards minimal smoothing, even if this means leaving a bit of noise in the photo. You can see these effects in the example photos later in this article.

One more thing. Many of our users prefer to shoot raw, not JPEGs, and they want these raw images to benefit from computational photography. (Some big cameras offer the ability to capture bursts of images and combine them in-camera, but they output a JPEG, not a raw file.) Indigo can output JPEG or raw files that benefit equally from the computational photography strategy outlined here. [...]

In reaction to the prevailing smartphone look, some camera apps advertise ‚Äúzero-process‚Äù photography. In fact, the pixels read from a digital sensor must be processed to create a recognizable image. This processing includes at a minimum white balancing, color correction to account for the different light sensitivity of the red, green and blue pixels, and demosaicing to create a full-color image. Based on our conversations with photographers, what they really want is not zero-process but a more natural look‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâmore like what an SLR might produce. To accomplish this, our photos employ only mild tone mapping, boosting of color saturation, and sharpening. We do perform semantically-aware mask-based adjustments, but only subtle ones.

You may recognize Levoy‚Äôs name. After a distinguished career at Stanford teaching computer science, Levoy spent 2014 to 2020 leading the computational photography team at Google for their highly-regarded-as-cameras Pixel phones. In 2020 Levoy left Google for Adobe, and Indigo is one of the first fruits of his time there.

Allison Johnson of The Verge‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äânotably, she came to The Verge by way of DPReview‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwrote a splendid piece on Indigo shortly after the app debuted, under the headline ‚ÄúAdobe‚Äôs New Camera App Is Making Me Rethink Phone Photography‚Äù:

If you hate the overly aggressive HDR look, or you‚Äôre tired of your iPhone sharpening the ever-living crap out of your photos, Project Indigo might be for you. It‚Äôs available in beta on iOS, though it is not‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand I stress this‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâfor the faint of heart. It‚Äôs slow, it‚Äôs prone to heating up my iPhone, and it drains the battery. But it‚Äôs the most thoughtfully designed camera experience I‚Äôve ever used on a phone, and it gave me a renewed sense of curiosity about the camera I use every day.

You‚Äôll know this isn‚Äôt your garden-variety camera app right from the onboarding screens. One section details the difference between two histograms available to use with the live preview image (one is based on Indigo‚Äôs own processing and one is based on Apple‚Äôs image pipeline). Another line describes the way the app handles processing of subjects and skies as ‚Äúspecial (but gentle).‚Äù This is a camera nerd‚Äôs love language.

Slow and battery-draining is exactly why Apple hasn‚Äôt pursued these sorts of advanced computational photography techniques in the built-in Camera app. Apple‚Äôs Camera app is super-fast and takes extraordinary effort to go easy on the battery. SATCOM Security‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâa team of researchers from UC San Diego and the University of Maryland:

We pointed a commercial-off-the-shelf satellite dish at the sky and carried out the most comprehensive public study to date of geostationary satellite communication. Maybe Apple was already planning a ‚Ç¨100 price cut for these new models. The M4 was ‚Ç¨100 less expensive than the M3 it replaced, for example, so it is plausible. That is something we simply cannot know. What we do know for certain is that these new MacBook Pros might not come with an A.C. adapter, but even if someone adds one at checkout, it still costs less in most places with this option.

The fact that the new M5 MacBook Pro costs less than the M4 models, even when paying extra to include a new power adapter, leads me to suspect that Apple was planning price cuts in these countries regardless. As Heer points out, Apple cut the price by ‚Ç¨100 when the base MacBook Pro went from the M3 to M4 a year ago. (MacBook Air prices have been getting lower worldwide, too.)

Anyway, the reason this regulation is subject to ridicule was never that European MacBook buyers were, effectively, paying for a charger that was no longer included. If Apple thought it was a good idea to no longer include power adapters in the box with MacBooks, they‚Äôd just stop including chargers in the box, worldwide. That‚Äôs what Apple started doing with iPhones with the iPhone 12 lineup five years ago. That wasn‚Äôt because of a law. It was because Apple thought it was a good idea.

The problem I see with the MacBook power adapter situation in Europe is that while power users‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâlike the sort of people who read Daring Fireball and Pixel Envy‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwill have no problem buying exactly the sort of power adapter they want, or simply re-using a good one they already own, normal users have no idea what makes a ‚Äúgood‚Äù power adapter. entry.title: More on the Lack of an Included Charger With New M5 MacBooks in Europe, Including the U.K. and Norway

While poking fun at EU regulations leading Apple not to include a power adapter with the new M5 MacBook Pro across Europe, I wondered why the U.K.‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwhich left the EU five years ago‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwas affected. DF reader C.A. wrote, via email:

We did indeed leave the EU, but remain aligned to some of their standards like food and consumer goods through a thing called the Windsor Framework. Because the UK includes Northern Ireland, which has an open border with the Republic of Ireland, and the RoI is part of the EU, and the border MUST remain open for historical reasons, there has to be a way of ensuring UK goods that don‚Äôt meet EU standards don‚Äôt enter the EU via Northern Ireland. entry.summary: Thoughts and observations on the new M5 MacBook Pro, iPad Pros, and Vision Pro.
entry.content:
Apple Newsroom, today:

Apple today announced M5, delivering the next big leap in AI performance and advances to nearly every aspect of the chip. Built using third-generation 3-nanometer technology, M5 introduces a next-generation 10-core GPU architecture with a Neural Accelerator in each core, enabling GPU-based AI workloads to run dramatically faster, with over 4√ó the peak GPU compute performance compared to M4. The GPU also offers enhanced graphics capabilities and third-generation ray tracing that combined deliver a graphics performance that is up to 45 percent higher than M4. M5 features the world‚Äôs fastest performance core, with up to a 10-core CPU made up of six efficiency cores and up to four performance cores. Together, they deliver up to 15 percent faster multithreaded performance over M4. M5 also features an improved 16-core Neural Engine, a powerful media engine, and a nearly 30 percent increase in unified memory bandwidth to 153GB/s. M5 brings its industry-leading power-efficient performance to the new 14-inch MacBook Pro, iPad Pro, and Apple Vision Pro, allowing each device to excel in its own way. All are available for pre-order today.

Some thoughts and observations:

14-Inch MacBook Pro

Apple Newsroom: ‚ÄúApple Unveils New 14‚ÄëInch MacBook Pro Powered by the M5 Chip, Delivering the Next Big Leap in AI for the Mac‚Äù.

The 14-inch MacBook Pro with the no-adjective M-series chip has always been an odd duck in the MacBook lineup. This ‚ÄúPro‚Äù-but-not-pro spot in the MacBook lineup goes back to the Intel era, when there was a 13-inch MacBook Pro without a Touch Bar. That was the MacBook Pro that, in 2016, Phil Schiller suggested as a good choice for those who were then holding out for a MacBook Air with a retina display. (The first retina MacBook Air didn‚Äôt ship for another two years, in late 2018.) It‚Äôs more like a MacBook ‚ÄúPro‚Äù than a MacBook Pro. The truly pro-spec‚Äôd MacBook Pros have M-series Pro and Max chips, and are available in both 14- and 16-inch sizes. The base 14-inch model, with the no-adjective M-series chip, is for people who probably would be better served with a MacBook Air but who wrongly believe they ‚Äúneed‚Äù a laptop with ‚ÄúPro‚Äù in its name.

Here‚Äôs a timeline of no-adjective M-series chips and when they appeared in the 14-inch MacBook Pro:

  • M1 13-inch MacBook Pro: 10 November 2020. This MacBook Pro was one of the three Macs that debuted with the launch of Apple Silicon‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthe others were the MacBook Air and Mac Mini. The hardware looked exactly like the last generation Intel MacBook Pro. The M1 Pro and M1 Max models didn‚Äôt ship for another year (well, 11 months later), and those models brought with them the new form factor design that‚Äôs still with us today with the new M5 MacBook Pro.

  • M2 13-inch MacBook Pro: 6 June 2022. This model also stuck with the older Intel-era form factor, including the 13-inch, not 14-inch, display size.

  • M3 14-inch MacBook Pro: 30 October 2023. The ‚ÄúScary Fast‚Äù event. This model debuted alongside the pro-spec‚Äôd M3 Pro and M3 Max 14- and 16-inch models.

  • M4 14-inch MacBook Pro: 30 October 2024. Exactly one year after the M3, and also alongside the M4 Pro and M4 Max models. What was different in 2024 with the M4 generation is that the M4 iPad Pros debuted back in early May, all by themselves.

  • M5 14-inch MacBook Pro: 15 October 2025 (today). What‚Äôs different with today‚Äôs announcement is that it is not alongside the M5 Pro and M5 Max models, but is alongside the M5 iPad Pros.

This raises the question of when to expect those M5 Pro/Max models. The rumor mill suggests ‚Äúearly 2026‚Äù. I suspect that‚Äôs right, based on nothing other than the fact that if they were going to be announced this year, Apple almost certainly would have announced the entire M5 generation MacBook lineup together.

Basically, this is just a speed bump upgrade over the just-plain M4 MacBook Pro. But annual‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâor at least regular‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâspeed bumps are a good thing. The alternative is years-long gaps between hardware refreshes.

iPad Pros

Apple Newsroom: ‚ÄúApple Introduces the Powerful New iPad Pro With the M5 Chip‚Äù:

Featuring a next-generation GPU with a Neural Accelerator in each core, M5 delivers a big boost in performance for iPad Pro users, whether they‚Äôre working on cutting-edge projects or tapping into AI for productivity. The new iPad Pro delivers up to 3.5√ó the AI performance than iPad Pro with M4 and up to 5.6√ó faster than iPad Pro with M1. N1, the new Apple-designed wireless networking chip, enables the latest generation of wireless technologies with support for Wi-Fi 7 on iPad Pro. The C1X modem comes to cellular models of iPad Pro, delivering up to 50 percent faster cellular data performance than its predecessor with even greater efficiency, allowing users to do more on the go.

I think the N1 wireless chip and C1X modem are more interesting generation-over-generation improvements than the M5 chip. Thanks to the N1, these iPad Pro models support Wi-Fi 7‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâtoday‚Äôs new M5 14-inch MacBook Pro does not. I would wager rather heavily that the upcoming M5 Pro and M5 Max MacBook Pro models will support Wi-Fi 7 (probably via the N1 chip, or perhaps even an ‚ÄúN1X‚Äù or something).

Other than that, this too is a speed bump upgrade.

Vision Pro

Apple Newsroom: ‚ÄúApple Vision Pro Upgraded With the M5 Chip and Dual Knit Band‚Äù:

The upgraded Vision Pro also comes with the soft, cushioned Dual Knit Band to help users achieve an even more comfortable fit, and visionOS 26, which unlocks innovative spatial experiences, including widgets, new Personas, an interactive Jupiter Environment, and new Apple Intelligence features with support for additional languages.

The new Dual Knit Band ($99 on its own) looks like a hybrid of the more attractive Solo Knit Band (which did not have a strap that went over the top of your head) and the Dual Loop Band (which did have an over-the-head strap, but which looked somewhat orthopedic). It‚Äôs a tacit acknowledgement that physical comfort has been a real problem for many people who‚Äôve tried Vision Pro. (Me, personally, I find using it with the Solo Knit Band comfortable for as long as I care to use it‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwhich is typically just 2‚Äì3 hours, tops.)

There are over 1 million apps and thousands of games on the App Store, hundreds of 3D movies on the Apple TV app, and all-new series and films in Apple Immersive with a selection of live NBA games coming soon.

Translation: Hey, there‚Äôs actually a growing library of immersive content to watch, software to use, and games to play for this thing now.

With M5, Apple Vision Pro renders 10 percent more pixels on the custom micro-OLED displays compared to the previous generation, resulting in a sharper image with crisper text and more detailed visuals. Vision Pro can also increase the refresh rate up to 120Hz for reduced motion blur when users look at their physical surroundings, and an even smoother experience when using Mac Virtual Display. Vision Pro with M5 works alongside the purpose-built R1 chip, which processes input from 12 cameras, five sensors, and six microphones, and streams new images to the displays within 12 milliseconds to create a real-time view of the world. The high-performance battery now supports up to two and a half hours of general use, and up to three hours of video playback, all on a single charge.

It‚Äôs merely another speed bump upgrade alongside the other two speed bump upgrades today, but a bit more dramatic given that the Vision Pro is jumping from the M2 to M5. No price drop, no change to the form factor. But Apple‚Äôs interest in the platform is very much alive.

ICEBlock developer Joshua Aaron, posting on the ICEBlock Bluesky account:

We just received a message from Apple‚Äôs App Review that #ICEBlock has been removed from the App Store due to ‚Äúobjectionable content‚Äù. The only thing we can imagine is this is due to pressure from the Trump Admin.

We have responded and we‚Äôll fight this! #resist

There is clearly nothing illegal about ICEBlock.1 It‚Äôs just information, obviously protected by the First Amendment. Law enforcement officers in the United States have no right to avoid being recorded nor their actions being reported and shared. Reporting and publishing where police are policing is free speech and fundamental to the civil rights and liberties of a free society.

We can all wish Apple had fought this ‚Äúdemand‚Äù. I certainly do. John Oliver‚Äôs ‚ÄúFuck you, make me‚Äù argument sprung to mind for me this morning. But that‚Äôs wishful thinking. I believe there are many lines Apple would not cross, even if it means taking on the ire of Trump administration lickspittles, if not the barely literate wrath of the mad king himself on his sad little blog. Apple may well eventually‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâif not soon‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbe forced to define those lines. But keeping ICEBlock in the App Store isn‚Äôt one of them. You might believe it should be. There‚Äôs a big part of me that believes it should be. But I can also see why it‚Äôs not. Pick your battles.

I wrote about ICEBlock twice back in late July. Quoting extensively from my initial post:

The ICEBlock app is interesting in and of itself (and from my tire-kicking test drive, appears to be a well-crafted and designed app), as will be Apple‚Äôs response if (when?) the Trump administration takes offense to the app‚Äôs existence. Back in 2019, kowtowing to tacit demands from China, Apple removed from the App Store an app called HKmap.live which helped pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong know the location of police and protest activity. The app broke no Hong Kong laws, but scared the thin-skinned skittish lickspittles in the Chinese Communist Party. (Remember too that in 2019, Apple removed the Taiwan flag emoji (üáπüáº) from the iOS 13 keyboard for users in Hong Kong and Macau.)

One defense from Apple regarding HKmap.live, however, was that the iOS app was a thin wrapper around the website, which website remained fully functional and could be saved to an iPhone user‚Äôs home screen. Removing the app from the App Store thus did not prevent Hongkongers from accessing it. (That website today seems to be defunct.)

ICEBlock is different. It is only available as a native iOS app. According to the developers, this is for technical reasons. From their web page explaining why they can‚Äôt offer an Android version:

At ICEBlock, user privacy and security are paramount. Our application is designed to provide as much anonymity as possible without storing any user data or creating accounts. While we understand the desire for an Android version of ICEBlock, achieving this level of anonymity on Android is not feasible due to the inherent requirements of push notification services.

To send push notifications on Android, it is necessary to use a mechanism that requires storing device IDs. This means that we would need to maintain a privately hosted database to store these identifiers. Storing such data, even if it‚Äôs anonymized, introduces significant privacy risks. [...]

In contrast, iOS offers us the flexibility to deliver push notifications while adhering strictly to our design philosophy. Apple‚Äôs ecosystem allows for push notifications to be sent without requiring us to store any user-identifiable information. This ensures that ICEBlock remains completely anonymous and secure.

To deliver push notifications on Android, the developers claim they would need to maintain a database of device IDs, create a user account system to manage those device IDs, and all of that server-stored data would be susceptible to law enforcement subpoenas and pro-ICE red hat hackers. (What ‚Äúbrown shirts‚Äù were to the Nazis, we should make ‚Äúred hats‚Äù to MAGA.)

To maintain anonymity and store zero user data, there is and can be no web app version of ICEBlock. There is and can be no Android version. Only iOS supports the security and privacy features for ICEBlock to offer what it does, the way it does. Here‚Äôs to hoping that Apple will proudly defend it if push comes to shove.

Apple‚Äôs removal of ICEBlock from the App Store is, in multiple ways, worse than Apple‚Äôs removal of HKmap.live from the App Store back in 2019. First, you cannot take a disagreement with the Chinese government to court. Here in the United States, you can. But Apple chose not to. That‚Äôs a display of weakness.

Second, from the perspective of users, without the HKmap.live ‚Äúapp‚Äù, Hong Kong iPhone users could still access all the functionality via the website, and the website could be saved to their home screens as a web app that was, I believe, functionally identical to the version from the App Store. I put ‚Äúapp‚Äù in quotes above because the HKmap.live app was really just a thin wrapper around the service‚Äôs mobile website. Hongkongers lost some convenience, and they lost the ability to tell non-technical protestor friends ‚Äújust get it from the App Store‚Äù, but it‚Äôs not that much more complex to explain how to add a website to your iPhone home screen as a web app.

With ICEBlock, the entire thing is simply no longer available. If you already have ICEBlock installed, the installed version still functions on your iPhone, but, until and if Apple changes its mind, there will be no further software updates and new users are unable to download it. Nor will current users be able to re-download the app on a new iPhone‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand now is ‚Äúnew iPhone‚Äù season. And, seemingly, there can be no web app (or Android) version of ICEBlock that offers the same level of anonymity as the native iOS version‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwith notifications, but without user accounts nor any database of device IDs for notifications that would be subject to subpoena from ICEBlock.

The gist of my second post on ICEBlock from back in July is that ICEBlock‚Äôs privacy-protecting architecture isn‚Äôt magic. It‚Äôs based on trust in Apple itself. Joshua Aaron doesn‚Äôt have access to ICEBlock users‚Äô device IDs (let alone their personal identities), but ICEBlock can send push notifications to devices because Apple itself does know device IDs and users‚Äô identities.

It‚Äôs rather chilling to consider what Apple would have done if the Trump administration had ‚Äúdemanded‚Äù a list of device IDs and user identities for everyone who had installed ICEBlock. Or what Apple will do if such a demand pops into one of their dimwitted but cruel minds.2 I suspect that‚Äôs one of the lines Apple would not cross. That Apple would stand its ground there and say ‚ÄúFuck you, make us‚Äù and take it to court. But there‚Äôs only one way to find out.

  1. It‚Äôs interesting to consider how Aaron might ‚Äúfight this‚Äù. I don‚Äôt think suing the Department of Justice is an option. All Pam Bondi did was issue a ‚Äúdemand‚Äù to Apple. That‚Äôs inappropriate and an embarrassment, and in any normal administration would be just cause for her immediate dismissal from the job. But it‚Äôs not against the law. She didn‚Äôt issue an unconstitutional legal demand to Apple. She just issued a verbal request with an implicit threat of turning the nation‚Äôs MAGA derps and Fox News junkies against Apple. What Apple was afraid of wasn‚Äôt fighting this demand in a court of law, but in the court of public opinion.

    So maybe Aaron sues Apple? I‚Äôm not sure he has grounds for that either, but it‚Äôd be interesting to see Apple‚Äôs lawyers argue in court that the App Store is no place for apps that protect users‚Äô civil liberties and personal privacy. ↩︎Ô∏é

  2. A few people have already asked me why it took the Trump administration several months to put ICEBlock in its crosshairs and issue a takedown ‚Äúdemand‚Äù to Apple. Aaron shipped the first release of ICEBlock back in April, and it achieved a significant amount of well-deserved publicity in July after Trump‚Äôs ICE goons began large-scale deportation raids in Los Angeles. My answer is simple: it took them months to issue this demand because they‚Äôre so goddamn stupid and incompetent. We should be thankful for that. In a competent regime attempting an authoritarian takeover of a liberal democracy, it would have been taken down in days, not months. ↩︎

entry.content:
Apple, ‚ÄúThe Digital Markets Act‚Äôs Impacts on EU Users‚Äù:

The DMA requires Apple to make certain features work on non-Apple products and apps before we can share them with our users. Unfortunately, that requires a lot of engineering work, and it‚Äôs caused us to delay some new features in the EU:

  • Live Translation with AirPods uses Apple Intelligence to let Apple users communicate across languages. Bringing a sophisticated feature like this to other devices creates challenges that take time to solve. For example, we designed Live Translation so that our users‚Äô conversations stay private‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâthey‚Äôre processed on device and are never accessible to Apple‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand our teams are doing additional engineering work to make sure they won‚Äôt be exposed to other companies or developers either.

  • iPhone Mirroring lets our users see and interact with their iPhone from their Mac, so they can seamlessly check their notifications, or drag and drop photos between devices. Our teams still have not found a secure way to bring this feature to non-Apple devices without putting all the data on a user‚Äôs iPhone at risk. And as a result, we have not been able to bring the feature to the EU. [...]

We‚Äôve suggested changes to these features that would protect our users‚Äô data, but so far, the European Commission has rejected our proposals. And according to the European Commission, under the DMA, it‚Äôs illegal for us to share these features with Apple users until we bring them to other companies‚Äô products. If we shared them any sooner, we‚Äôd be fined and potentially forced to stop shipping our products in the EU.

Live Translation with AirPods and iPhone Mirroring are both amazing features. And EU users are missing out on them. I think Apple structured this piece exactly right, by emphasizing first that the most direct effect of the DMA is that EU users are getting great features late‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâor never. And that list of features is only going to grow over time.

Under the section ‚ÄúIs the DMA Achieving Its Goals?‚Äù:

Regulators claimed the DMA would promote competition and give European consumers more choices. But the law is not living up to those promises. In fact, it‚Äôs having some of the opposite effects:

  • Fewer choices: When features are delayed or unavailable, EU users don‚Äôt get the same options as users in the rest of the world. They lose the choice to use Apple‚Äôs latest technologies, and their devices fall further behind.

  • Less differentiation: By forcing Apple to build features and technologies for non-Apple products, the DMA is making the options available to European consumers more similar. For instance, the changes to app marketplaces are making iOS look more like Android‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand that reduces choice.

  • Unfair competition: The DMA‚Äôs rules only apply to Apple, even though Samsung is the smartphone market leader in Europe, and Chinese companies are growing fast. Apple has led the way in building a unique, innovative ecosystem that others have copied‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâto the benefit of users everywhere. But instead of rewarding that innovation, the DMA singles Apple out while leaving our competitors free to continue as they always have.

This is all true. But I have a better way to put this. If Apple were to just switch the iPhone‚Äôs OS from iOS to Android, these DMA conflicts would all go away. Apple‚Äôs not going to do that, of course, but to me it‚Äôs a crystallizing way of looking at it. The DMA is supposedly intended to increase ‚Äúcompetition‚Äù, which in turn should increase consumer choice. But the easiest way for Apple to comply with the DMA would be to switch EU iPhones to Android‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwhich, by a significant margin, already has majority mobile OS market share in the EU. Here‚Äôs a link to StatCounter‚Äôs mobile OS stats for Europe (which is not the same as the EU, but as good a proxy as I could find). It‚Äôs two-thirds Android, one-third iOS‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâa 2-1 ratio.

If Apple just shipped all EU iPhones with Android instead of iOS, all of their DMA problems would be off the table. EU iPhone users would lose all iOS exclusive features and Apple device Continuity integrations. EU consumers would effectively have no choice at all in mobile OSes. They‚Äôd just get to choose which brand of Android phone to buy.

How in the world would that increase competition? iOS‚Äôs unique and exclusive features‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwhich, yes, in many cases, are exclusive to the Apple device ecosystem‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâare competition.
